Line 6

<b>כל האומר לא לויתי כאומר כולי—Whoever says I did not borrow, it is if he said, etc.</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The ברייתא states that if a לוה originally admits (in the presence of witnesses) that he owes money and then subsequently denies that he ever borrowed; the ruling is that he liable to pay the debt. The גמרא cites the dictum of 'כל האומר וכו as the reason for this ruling. Seemingly this dictum is not at all necessary to obligate the לוה. He is liable because he cannot contradict his previous admission of owing the monies. תוספות will be addressing this issue.<br>----------------------<br>תוספות asks:<br><b>הקשה הרב רבינו יצחק מה צריך כאן לטעם כל האומר כולי –</b><br><b>The ר"י</b> <b>asks: why is it necessary here to</b> utilize <b>the explanation</b> of <b>whoever says, etc.</b> I did not borrow is as if he said I did not repay. This idea is superfluous in the case under discussion. For in our case –<br><b>הא ודאי כיון שכבר הודה תו לא מהימן לומר שלא לוה –</b><br><b>Since he already admitted</b> that he owes money, then <b>certainly he will not be believed to restate</b> and claim <b>that he did not borrow.</b> Once an admission is made, one cannot retract the admission.<br>תוספות will now explain where this dictum is necessary:<br><b>דבשלמא בשבועות (דף מא,ב ושם דיבור המתחיל כל) צריך להאי טעמא –</b><br><b>It is understood</b> that <b>in</b> מסכת <b>שבועות this reasoning</b> of<b></b> 'כל האומר וכו <b>is necessary;</b> for there the גמרא is discussing a case –<br><b>שאומר לו מנה לי בידך והלה אומר לא היו דברים מעולם –</b><br><b>Where</b> the מלוה <b>says to</b> the לוה ‘<b>you owe me a</b> מנה (a hundred זוז)’ [literally I have a מנה in your hand] <b>and this</b> לוה <b>responds: ‘It never happened;</b> you never lent me money’ –<br><b>ואתו עדים ואמרי ראינו שלוה ופרע –</b><br><b>And witnesses came and testified</b> that ‘<b>we saw that he borrowed money</b> and <b>subsequently</b> <b>repaid</b> it’ –<br><b>השתא הא דקאמרי סהדי שלוה מהימני והא דקאמרי פרע<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The הגהות הב"ח amends this to read שפרע.</i> לא מהימני –</b><br><b>Now</b> we view this case as follows; <b>that which the witnesses testify that</b> the לוה <b>borrowed, they are believed.</b> We have therefore substantiated that the לוה owed money to the מלוה. <b>However that which they testify [that] he repaid</b> the loan – <b>they are not believed.</b> We assume that he still owes the money. The reason the witnesses are not believed that he repaid the loan, is –<br><b>דהא איהו קמכחיש להו דאמר לא לויתי והאומר לא לויתי כאומר לא פרעתי דמי –</b><br><b>for</b> the לוה <b>himself contradicts them, since</b> the לוה <b>said I did not borrow</b> any money from this מלוה <b>and one who says I did not borrow it is as if he said I did not repay</b> the loan. The לוה by claiming לא לויתי it is as if he is admitting that he did not repay. Therefore even though that the עדים testify that he did pay, his inferred admission that he did not pay is stronger than the testimony of the witnesses. A person is believed for his detriment, even against the testimony of witnesses.<br>In מסכת שבועות it is understood why it is necessary to use the rationale of 'כל האומר וכו; otherwise he would be exempt from payment since the עדים are testifying that he repaid the loan (and he did not explicitly say that he did not pay) –<br><b>אבל הכא לא צריך כלל –</b><br><b>however here</b> in our case where he originally admitted to owing the money <b>it is entirely not necessary</b> to depend on the rationale of 'כל האומר וכו; for even without that reasoning he would still be obligated to pay, since originally he admitted that he owed the money, he cannot later retract and claim there was never such a loan.<br>תוספות answers:<br><b>ואומר רבינו יצחק דאיצטריך לאשמועינן דלא מצי למימר האומר<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The הגהות הב"ח amends this to read הא דאמרי.</i> לא לויתי –</b><br><b>And the ר"י</b> <b>says it is necessary</b> to cite the rationale of 'כל האומר וכו, in order <b>to let us know that</b> the לוה <b>cannot</b> argue and <b>say [that which I</b> subsequently <b>stated]</b> that <b>I did not borrow</b> from you anything,<br><b>לא שלא לוה<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The הגהות הב"ח amends this to read לויתי.</i> כלל אלא כאילו לא לויתי לפי שפרעתי –</b><br>I did <b>not</b> mean <b>that [I] did not borrow at all</b> from you <b>but</b> rather I meant that <b>it is as if I never borrowed</b> from you <b>because I repaid</b> the loan. When I claimed לא לויתי, I meant to say that as of now it is as if I never borrowed money from you since I already repaid it. Therefore were it not for the rule that ''כל האומר וכו', he might be believed, since according to his interpretation of his subsequent claim of לא לויתי he is not contradicting his original admission of owing money. That is why –<br><b>קא משמע לן דכאילו אומר לא פרעתי בהדיא:</b><br>The גמרא <b>comes to let us know</b> by citing the ruling of ''כל האומר וכו', that when a person claims לא לויתי he cannot later reinterpret his statement to mean that I repaid you and it is as if I never borrowed. This is not so, but rather the statement of לא לויתי is <b>as if he explicitly stated I did not (</b>borrow and certainly did not) <b>repay</b> the loan. <b><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">If we were able to reinterpret לא לויתי to mean לויתי ופרעתי, then how come in שבועות 'מס he is not believed; especially since there are עדים who testify that he paid, let us reinterpret his לא לויתי as לויתי ופרעתי which would make him in full accord with the עדים. Once I see that we do not reinterpret לא לויתי even when it is in accordance with עדים then we will certainly not reinterpret it to mean ופרעתי לוית when it is not corroborated by עדים. See ‘Thinking it over’ # 2</i></b> Therefore he cannot reinterpret his claim of לא לויתי; but rather we take it to mean לא לויתי ולא פרעתי.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>The dictum 'כל האומר וכו is effective in extracting a (tacit) admission from the לוה that he did not pay (even against conflicting testimony), and also preventing the לוה from reinterpreting לא לויתי to mean לויתי ופרעתי.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>תוספות maintains that without 'כל האומר וכו, the לוה could reinterpret לא לויתי to mean לא לויתי ופרעתי. However our גמרא states that the subsequent claim of the לוה was להד"ם. It would seem a bit far to reinterpret להד"ם to mean לויתי ופרעתי (even without  כל האומר).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See סוכ"ד אות ד.</i><br>Can we differentiate between what the כל האומר  accomplishes in שבועות to what it accomplishes here in our גמרא?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See footnote # 4.</i>

Line 7

<b>סמך לפלגא סמך לכולה—Joining for half, is joining for the whole</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא cited the view of רב הונא, that if the new wall that was placed adjacent to the original wall was only half the size of the original wall, nevertheless he is required to pay for half of the entire original wall. The reason is because we assume that eventually he will enlarge the new wall to the same dimensions as the original wall, and utilize the entire original wall.<br>-------------------------------<br><b>האי לפלגא איירי בין לאורך בין לגובה:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">One may have thought that the rule of סמך לפלגא סמך לכולא is only when it was as long as the original wall but not as high; for it is customary to build a wall upwards, row by row, therefore it is likely that he will eventually build it up to the height of the dividing wall. However if the wall did not extend the full length of the dividing wall I may have thought that it is unusual to extend it sideways in the length. See following תוספות ד"ה ומודה, for a possible proof/explanation why תוספות maintains that סמך לפלגא is in both dimensions.</i></b><br><b>This</b> statement, that the new wall was <b>half</b> the size of the old wall, <b>is discussing</b> both cases; <b>whether</b> it was half <b>the length</b> of the original wall, or <b>whether</b> it was <b>half</b> the height <b>of the original wall.</b> In both cases the same rule applies; that it is סמך לכולה, and he must pay for the cost of half the original wall.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>It makes no difference whether the new (adjoining) wall was smaller than the original wall in height or length; in both cases he must pay for half of the entire original wall.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>What would be the דין if the new wall was smaller than the original wall in both length <i>and </i>height?

Line 8

<b>ומודה רב הונא בקרנא ולופתא—And </b>רב הונא<b> admits by a ‘corner’ and an ‘angle’</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>After the גמרא cited the dispute between ר"ה and ר"נ whether we say סמך לפלגא סמך לכולא or למאי דסמך סמך, the גמרא concludes that ר"ה admits to ר"נ by קרנא ולופתא and ר"נ admits to ר"ה by אפריזא ובאקבעתא דכשורי. In the previous תוספות (ד"ה סמך) we learnt that the מחלוקת between ר"ה ור"נ is in a case where the new wall is shorter than the party wall either in height or in length. It is therefore preferable to assume that the 'ומודה' of both ר"ה ור"נ refer to both types of cases where the new wall was shorter than the party wall either in height or length.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In support of this assumption is that the גמרא (seemingly) mentions two cases by each 'ומודה'. This also indicates that the 'ומודה' is in the two types of סמך לפלגא. See the מפרשים why רש"י disagrees with 'תוס.</i> תוספות will explain that this is indeed so. Each one was מודה to the other in these two types of סמך לפלגא.<br>---------------------------<br><b>מפרש רבינו תם קרנא להיכר שלא יאריך החומה יותר –</b><br><b>The ת"ר</b> <b>explains that the ‘corner’</b> that was made in the new wall, <b>is for a sign that he will not lengthen the wall further.</b> תוספות goes on to explain, how in the case of 'קרנא', we can assume that the wall will not be extended any longer –<br><b>שבסוף אותו כותל שסמך<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The הגהות הב"ח amends this to read שסמך עושה כיפיה לקרנא.</i> כייפיה לקרנא כלפי כותלו של חבירו –</b><br><b>For at the end of the wall which he juxtaposed</b> to the party wall <b>he turned the corner</b> of the wall <b>towards his friend’s</b> party <b>wall.</b>. He discontinued extending the wall; but rather began building at a right angle to his wall, which caused his wall to extend in the direction towards his friend’s party wall. In this case רב הונא will admit that we do not say סמך לפלגא סמך לכולא, since it is obvious that he will not extend his wall lengthwise anymore; but rather we maintain that למאי דסמך סמך. This explains the case of shorter in length.<br>תוספות will now explain the case where it was shorter in height:<br><b>ולופתא הוי היכר שלא יגביה הכותל יותר –</b><br><b>And 'לופתא',</b> a (pitched) angle <b>is a sign that he will not raise the wall higher.</b> תוספות goes on to explain –<br><b>כגון שעשה היכר בראש החומה<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The הגהות הב"ח amends this to read החומה כמו שרגילים. </i> לפי שרגילין לעשות החומה צרה למעלה –</b><br><b>for instance; that he made an indication at the top of the wall,</b> that he is not building higher <b>(for) [as] it is customary to make the wall narrow on top;</b> it is pitched at an angle –<br><b>שיפלו הגשמים מחוץ לחומה ולא ישהו שם –</b><br><b>So that the rain</b> water <b>will fall down away from the wall and will not remain there,</b> on top of the wall; which may cause water damage. A wall pitched on top is not extended any higher. When he built the לופתא on the wall, we are assured that he will not raise the wall any higher. Again, רב הונא will admit in this case, that 'למאי דסמך סמך וכו.<br>תוספות has concluded citing both cases according to ר"ה.<br>תוספות continues to explain both cases according to ר"נ.<br><b>ומודה רב נחמן באפריזא היא היכר שיאריך עדיין הכותל –</b><br><b>And ר"נ admits</b> to ר"ה <b>in the case of a broken staggered wall.</b> תוספות explains that אפריזא <b>is an indication that he yet</b> intends <b>to lengthen the wall.</b> תוספות explains that אפריזא means –<br><b>שבסוף אורך החומה אינו שוה אלא אבן אחת בולטת ואחת שוקעת דודאי עדיין יאריכנו –</b><br><b>That at the end of the length of the wall it is not straight</b> and finished properly <b>but rather</b> the stones are staggered, <b>one stone protrudes</b> lengthwise <b>and one</b> stone <b>is indented</b> lengthwise, <b>for</b> in this case <b>he will yet certainly lengthen</b> the wall. נחמן רב will agree that in this instance we maintain סמך לפלגא סמך לכולא.<br>תוספות will now discuss the case of a lower wall according to ר"נ.<br><b>ואקבעתא דכשורי היינו שעשה מקום הנחת ראשי קורות<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The crossbeams generally serve as a floor for the attic above.</i> –</b><br><b>And the placement of the crossbeams that means that he made</b> on top of the new wall <b>place to put the ends of the crossbeams.</b><br><b>דמוכח שסופו להגביה עד שיעור גובה עלייה:</b><br><b>For</b> then <b>it is evident that ultimately he will raise</b> the wall <b>up to the height of an attic;</b> he intends to build a second story, which will eventually raise the height of his wall to the same height as the party wall.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>Both ר"ה and ר"נ agree that if there is a clear indication that the new wall will be definitely not extended in length or height; or that it will be definitely extended either in length or height, that we follow this indication, concerning סמך לכולא or למאי דסמך סמך.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>When a person begins to build a wall adjacent to a party wall, at what point is he obligated to pay for the party wall? Can he eventually exempt himself from full payment?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See סוכ"ד אות ט.</i>

Daf 6b

Line 2

<b>האי כשורא דמטללתא—This beam of a</b> (temporary) <b>hut</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>רבינא teaches us that if one places a beam [to support the roof of a temporary hut] on his neighbor’s wall; if it stood there for less than thirty days it is not considered a חזקה;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Even if the owner of the wall did not protest during the entire thirty day period, it is not a חזקה.</i> if it remained there more than thirty days, without the owner of the wall protesting, it is considered a חזקה for the owner of that beam.<br>The question arises; in reference to what, are we discussing whether or not it is a חזקה. Presumably it would seem that it is in reference to whether or not the owner of the beam may keep the beam on the other person’s wall indefinitely.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See רש"י ד"ה לא הויא חזקה.</i> This type of a חזקה is called חזקת תשמישין; the right to use another person’s property.<br>However this presents a difficulty according to some opinions. There is a dispute among the ראשונים as to how חזקת תשמישין is established. According to certain opinions (the 'תוס mentioned in רש"י דף ו,א ד"ה תוס' אחזיק להורדי and others) this חזקה is established immediately; as soon as the owner is aware that someone is using his property and he does not protest, the user acquires the right to continue using his neighbor’s property (in this manner) forever.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">There is a further dispute in this opinion itself. Some maintain ('תוס mentioned in רש"י) that the מחזיק must have a claim, that he either bought this right or it was gifted to him. However others maintain that he needs no טענה, the mere fact that the owner did not protest indicates that the owner gave up his exclusive right to the property and is מוחל it to the user.</i> Other ראשונים, however maintain that this חזקת תשמישין can be acquired only if it was utilized for three years, without any protest from the owner, and the user claims that the owner sold him or gifted him the right of usage.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The question arises; why are thirty days required by a כשורא דמטללתא? It should either be immediately or after three years. Those that maintain that חזקת תשמישין is immediately; they will answer that since it was a beam which supported a temporary hut, the owner would not mind, for up to thirty days. However more than thirty days indicates that it is not temporary anymore, therefore if he does not protest after thirty days the user acquires the חזקת תשמישין for this כשורא. However according to the ר"ת who maintains that even חזקת תשמישין requires a three year חזקה, why is there a חזקה by a כשורא דמטללתא in only thirty days; it should require three years.  תוספות addresses this issue</i><br>--------------------------<br><b>אומר רבינו תם דאמתניתין קאי דעד שלשים יום לא הוי חזקה והוי בחזקת שלא נתן –</b><br><b>The ר"ת says; that</b> this rule concerning the כשורא דמטללתא, <b>is referencing</b> back to <b>our משנה.</b><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The משנה stated that if the neighbor built an adjacent wall next to the dividing wall (which belonged to the other party), he is liable for the expense of the party wall, even if he did not place a roof over both walls. The משנה continues there, that he is assumed not to have paid for the dividing wall unless he can substantiate his payment. The inference from the משנה may be that if he put a roof over both walls and claims that he paid for his share in the dividing wall he will be believed. The reason is, because the original owner would not permit him to place a roof over the party wall unless he paid up for his half of the wall.</i> The ר"ת says that our גמרא is discussing a case where he placed (merely) a כשורא דמטללתא over both walls. רבינא says that the דין is that <b>until thirty days</b> have passed since he placed the כשורא דמטללתא on the dividing wall, <b>it is not considered</b> yet <b>that he has a חזקה,</b> for since it is a temporary structure the owner may not mind his using the wall <b>and therefore it is</b> still <b>presumed that he did not pay</b> for the dividing wall unless he brings proof to substantiate his claim. However –<br><b>מכאן ואילך הוי בחזקת שנתן<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The ר"ת explains that we are not discussing here חזקת תשמישין, for that would require a three year חזקה. Rather the second party who built the adjacent wall becomes obligated to pay for the party wall. Our גמרא is discussing at what point he is considered בחזקת שלא נתן and when he is considered בחזקת שנתן. It is obvious that if he built a finished roof over both walls without the owner protesting, that he is בחזקת שנתן immediately; otherwise why did the original owner of the dividing wall allow him to place a permanent roof over the dividing wall. It must be because he paid him already for his half of the wall. By a כשורא דמטללתא, however, which is a temporary roof; thirty days are required for him to be considered בחזקת שנתן.</i> –</b><br><b>From</b> thirty days <b>onward;</b> once thirty days have passed since he placed the כשורא דמטללתא on the dividing wall and his neighbor did not protest <b>it is presumed that he paid</b> for his share in the dividing wall, and if he claims that indeed he paid it, he is not required to substantiate his claim.<br>תוספות adds that by interpreting this case as referencing our משנה, (as opposed to חזקת תשמישין) there is an (additional) advantage.<br><b>ואתי שפיר דנקטיה הכא ולא בחזקת הבתים:</b><br><b>And it properly</b> understood <b>that he mentions</b> this ruling <b>here and not in</b> פרק <b>חזקת הבתים.</b> If we are discussing a חזקה of ownership and rights; then that belongs in פרק חזקת הבתים, not here in this פרק, where we are discussing the rules of division of property.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">See ‘Thinking it over’.</i><br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>In a case of סמך לו כותל and then he placed a כשורא דמטללתא over the party wall; if it remained there for (over) thirty days he is בחזקת שנתן.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>The ר"ת maintains that if we were discussing חזקת תשמישין, this case of כשורא דמטללתא should have been mentioned in חזקת הבתים. Why then does the גמרא mention here the laws of 'אחזיק לכושרי אחזיק להורדי וכו; they are certainly laws of חזקת תשמישין?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See footnote # 7. See רא"ש beginning of סי' יד.</i>
<b>עד שבעה יומי—Until seven days</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא teaches us that if someone places his beams on his neighbor’s wall for a סוכה, even if the owner of the wall did not protest, it is not a חזקה, until after (the) seven days (of סוכות) have passed. The owner of the wall does not mind if his neighbor uses his wall for a סוכה.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">A חזקה against an owner is established only if the action taken against him should cause him to protest.</i> If, however, סוכות passes and the owner does not protest, and demand that he remove the beams, then he has established a חזקה to place his beams on his neighbor’s wall. תוספות will be discussing the inference of the statement עד שבעה יומי; namely that after seven days passed it is a חזקה. Seemingly this is incorrect.<br>---------------------------<br><b>לאו דוקא שבעה דבשמיני עצרת לא יוכל לסתור:</b><br><b>It is not precisely</b> (only) <b>seven</b> days that are required before it is considered a חזקה, it is actually not a חזקה until all the days of יום טוב pass, including שמע"צ (<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The גמרא and תוספות may (also) be discussing those places where there is no ספיקא דיומא.</i>ושמח"ת). <b>For he cannot dismantle</b> the סוכה <b>on עצרת שמיני</b> (or תורה שמחת); there is an איסור of dismantling on יום טוב. We cannot say that if the סוכה was not dismantled on רבה הושענא, then he has a חזקה. The owner does not mind that he keep the סוכה until after the completion of the entire יום טוב. Even if the owner would protest he would not be able to remove it.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>The חזקה of a סוכה is only if the owner did not protest after the entire יום טוב passed.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>1. Why could not the owner demand that he dismantle the סוכה on הושענה רבה towards the end of the day (if we were to assume that there is no obligation to eat in the סוכה on יום טוב)?<br>2. Why indeed did רבינא say עד שבעה יומין?
<b>ואי חבריה בטינא לאלתר הוי חזקה—And if he bonded it with cement, it is a חזקה immediately</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא states that if a כשורא דמטללתא is placed on a neighbor’s wall and cemented there, it is immediately considered a חזקה. This תוספות maintains that it is a חזקה in regards that the owner of the כשורא may keep it there forever, without having to remove it.<br>--------------------<br><b>ואומר רבינו שמואל<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See in רש"י ו,א ד"ה תוס'.</i> דחזקות דלעיל לאו דשלש שנים<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">A חזקה to establish ownership of קרקע requires three years. However a חזקה to establish a right of usage in a neighbor’s property – חזקת תשמישין, that can be accomplished immediately (if the owner does not protest).</i> אלא לאלתר<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">This viewpoint of the רשב"ם is in opposition to the viewpoint of the ר"ת brought in the previous תוס' ד"ה האי, who maintains that חזקת תשמישין also require three years to be established. The ר"ת maintains that the discussion about a כשורא דמטללתא is in regards to the question if he is to be considered בחזקת שנתן or not, in the case of סמך לו כותל אחר, but not in regard to חזקת תשמישין.</i> כדאמרינן הכא:</b><br><b>And the</b> [ב"ם]<b>רש</b> <b>says that the</b> חזקות mentioned <b>previously</b>, such as אחזיק להורדי or אחזיק לנטפי <b>are not</b> חזקות which require <b>three years</b> to be established <b>but</b> rather they take effect <b>immediately.</b> If the aggrieved party is aware of the action taken and does not protest, it is a חזקה immediately, <b>as</b> the גמרא <b>states here</b> that if he bonded the beam to the wall with cement it is a חזקה immediately, similarly with the other חזקות mentioned previously in our גמרא.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>חזקת תשמישין is accomplished immediately.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>Why (according to the רשב"ם וסייעתו) is there a difference between חזקת קרקע which requires three years and חזקת תשמישין where it is a חזקה לאלתר?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See נח"מ ו,א בגמ' ד"ה ונ"ל להסביר.</i><br>2. If חזקת תשמישין is established immediately by אחזיק להורדי וכו', why are thirty days required to establish a חזקה by a כשורא דמטללתא?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See סוכ"ד אות כד.</i>

Line 3

<b>בשני צדי רשות הרבים—On the two sides of a public domain</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>אביי taught that if there are two houses on opposite sides of a רה"ר each owner is required to build a מעקה for half his roof, so that there should be no היזק ראיה from one roof to the other. The question that arises is, did אביי mean that <i>even</i> if they are on opposite sides we are concerned for היזק ראיה, and certainly if they are on the same side adjacent to each other; or did אביי mean that <i>only</i> if they are on opposite sides is there a concern of היזק ראיה.<br>------------------------------<br><b>אומר רבינו יצחק דוקא בשני צדי רשות הרבים<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The same rule applies for two sides of a רה"ר as the גמרא states.</i> –</b><br><b>The ר"י</b> <b>says</b> that the rule of 'עושה מעקה לחצי גגו וכו, is <b>only</b> if the two houses are <b>on two</b> opposite <b>sides of a</b> רה"ר<b>;</b> it is only then that we require each one to build a מעקה לחצי גגו<br><b>שאין האחד מרגיש בחבירו כשעולה בגגו שיזהר ממנו –</b><br><b>Since one</b> neighbor <b>is not aware when his friend goes up to his roof that he should be careful on account of him.</b> Therefore there is a concern of היזק ראיה<b>.</b> However if the two houses are not בשני צדי רה"ר, but are close (or attached) to each other, then there is no requirement that they build a מעקה לחצי גגו. If someone is doing something on his roof, he will be immediately aware if his neighbor is coming up to the roof, since they are close to each other. There will be no היזק ראיה.<br>תוספות proves this:<br><b>מדאמרינן בסמוך אבל בין גג לגג לא:</b><br><b>As</b> the גמרא <b>will shortly state</b>; that a לחצר הסמוך גג requires a מעקה of ד' אמות, <b>however between</b> one <b>roof to</b> another <b>roof there is no</b> requirement to build a מעקה.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>The rule of עושה מעקה לחצי גגו is only if the roofs are בשני צדי רה"ר but not if they are adjacent to each other.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>If there is no היזק ראיה by a גג when he is aware of his neighbor’s presence, then there should certainly be no היזק ראיה by a חצר, for he is surely aware of his neighbor’s presence. Why is there a difference between a חצר and a גג?!<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See נח"מ.</i>

Line 5



Line 6



Line 7

<b>מהו דתימא מצי אמר ליה שקול אוזינקא כולי—You may have said; he can tell him ‘take your expenses, etc’.</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא states that (were it not for אביי) we may have thought that if one of the neighbors (A) build half the מעקה on his property, then his neighbor directly across the רה"ר (B), could coerce him (A) to finish building the entire מעקה on his (A) property (paying him for half the expense of the entire מעקה). Our תוספות will analyze this הוה אמינא (and the מסקנא).<br>--------------------------<br>תוספות asks:<br><b>ואם תאמר והיכי הוי סלקא דעתין דמצי למימר ליה הכי –</b><br><b>And if you will say; how could it have entered our minds that he could have told him so; ‘</b>complete the מעקה and I will pay for the expense’ <b>–</b><br><b>דאטו משום דקדם זה ועשה הורע כחו ויכול לדוחקו זה לעשות כל הכותל –</b><br><b>Is it</b> justified <b>that just because this one</b> (who) <b>went ahead and built</b> half the מעקה, therefore <b>his strength is diminished,</b> to the extent <b>that the other can force him to build the entire</b> protective <b>wall!<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Originally neither of the two can force the other to build a complete מעקה. If in fact ראובן built half the מעקה first, why can שמעון force ראובן to complete the entire מעקה? It is not logical to assume that s'ראובן position has become weaker because he built half the מעקה first. If originally שמעון could not coerce ראובן to build the מעקה why would I even think that he can coerce him now!</i></b><br>תוספות answers:<br><b>ויש לומר דסלקא דעתין כיון דאם לא קדם זה ועשה זה<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The הגהות הב"ח deletes this (second) זה.</i> –<br>And one can say that we may have thought that since if one</b> of them <b>would not have gone ahead and built</b> half the מעקה, then either –<br><b>הוה מצי למימר שקול אוזינקא וזיל ועשה כל הכותל –</b><br><b>One would be entitled to say</b> to the other; ‘either <b>take</b> from me half <b>the expense</b> of the מעקה <b>and build the entire</b> מעקה on your property –<br><b>או הב לי אוזינקא ואעשה אני הכל ונרויח בין שנינו שלא נצטרך להעדיף –</b><br><b>Or give me</b> half <b>the expense and I will build the entire</b> מעקה on my property. The reason either one of them can coerce his neighbor to accept either of these two options is because the initiator can claim that by doing it in this manner - that one of us builds the entire מעקה on his property <b>then we will both profit, for we will not need</b> to build <b>the extension.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">If we will both build the מעקה, half on each side of the רה"ר, then both of us will have to pay for more than half a מעקה, for we will need to extend the מעקה more than halfway; as the גמרא clearly states ומעדיף. However if one of us builds the entire מעקה then we will both save the expense of this extension. Therefore since originally שמעון could have coerced ראובן to either build the entire מעקה (or pay שמעון to build the entire מעקה), it is apparent that שמעון did have some right over ראובן; to disallow him to build (only) half a wall.</i></b> It would follow that –<br><b>השתא נמי מצי למימר ליה הכי –</b><br><b>Now</b> that ראובן built half the מעקה, שמעון <b>should still be able to tell him</b> to finish building the מעקה on s'ראובן property. This way they will be each saving the cost of the extension; therefore –<br><b>קא משמע לן דלא מצי אמר ליה כיון שכבר עשה זה ולא אמר לו קודם:</b><br>אביי <b>comes to teach us that</b> שמעון <b>cannot tell</b> ראובן you must finish building the מעקה to save the expense of the extension. The reason is <b>since</b> ראובן <b>already made</b> half the מעקה <b>and</b> שמעון <b>said nothing to him beforehand.</b> The fact that שמעון did not approach ראובן initially with this offer, that either you make the entire מעקה or I will make the entire מעקה, indicates that שמעון was not interested in making the entire מעקה on his property; as the גמרא states that he does not want to weaken his existing wall.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">This understanding of תוספות serves to integrate the תירוצים of the גמרא and תוספות. See מהר"ם.</i> Therefore by not approaching ראובן initially (before ראובן built half the מעקה), שמעון relinquished his right of coercing ראובן to build the entire מעקה on one property.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The only right שמעון had, was to offer ראובן a choice. If שמעון is not interested in building on his property, then there is no choice and hence also no right.</i><br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>Two people on opposite sides of a רה"ר; either one of them can coerce the other to accept the proposition that one build the entire wall and the other pay for half the expenses. The decision as to who builds, etc. lies with the one accepting the option, not the initiator. This explains the הו"א that he could coerce the builder of half the מעקה to complete it. The מסקנא is that since he did not make this offer (in order not to harm his wall), he relinquished the right to enforce this option.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>תוספות states that originally each neighbor has the option to coerce his partner to either build the entire מעקה, or have the initiator build it entirely. Why indeed do they have this right to coerce the neighbor?! Why cannot the neighbor claim I wish to have just half a wall on my property, even if it cost a little more?!<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See נתיה"מ (ביאורים) סי' קס סק"א ועי' בבל"י סי' קמג. </i>

<b>שתי חצרות זו למעלה מזו—Two courtyards one above the other</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא discusses the case of two adjoining חצרות, where the ground level of one is higher than the other. There is a dispute whether the owner of the upper חצר must contribute to that part of the wall which is below his ground level. However there is no dispute as to the responsibility of the lower s'חצר owner. He is required to assist in building the dividing wall for the full ד' אמות above the ground level of the upper חצר.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See ‘Thinking it over’ # 1.</i> תוספות will be discussing the reason for this ruling.<br>-------------------------<br>תוספות asks:<br><b>ואם תאמר ותחתון למה יסייע לעליון –</b><br><b>And if you will say; and why should</b> the owner of <b>the lower</b> חצר <b>assist</b> the owner of <b>the upper</b> חצר to build up to four אמות above the ground level of the upper חצר?!<br><b>דמכי מטי לארבע אמות ולא יוכל התחתון לראות בחצר העליון יבנה העליון –</b><br><b>For when</b> the wall <b>reaches four</b> אמות from the ground level of the lower חצר, at which point <b>the</b> owner of <b>the lower</b> חצר <b>cannot see into the upper</b> חצר<b>;</b> that should be sufficient for the בעל התחתון, since he can no longer cause היזק ראיה to the חצר העליון. In order to prevent היזק ראיה from the חצר העליון to the תחתון, that upper part of the wall <b>should be built</b> by the owner of <b>the upper</b> חצר; who alone is causing the היזק ראיה.<br>תוספות answers:<br><b>ואומר רבינו תם כגון שחצר התחתון אינו נמוך אלא<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The מהרש"ל keeps the word אלא, while the מהרש"א deletes it.</i> אצל חצרו של עליון (אלא מצד א')<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See מסורת הש"ס that others delete this phrase (in parenthesis).</i> –</b><br><b>And the ר"ת says</b> that we are discussing a situation where <b>for instance that the lower</b> חצר <b>is not lower</b> than the upper חצר in its entirety, but rather it is lower <b>only where it is close to the חצר of</b> <b>his higher neighbor (only on one side) –<br>ומצד א' הוא גבוה כחצר העליון שיוכל לראות שם –</b><br><b>However from the other side</b> of the lower חצר where it is not close to the חצר העליון, there the חצר התחתון <b>is as high as his neighbor’s חצר (as the חצר העליון).</b> The חצר התחתון slopes. It is low adjacent to the חצר העליון and it rises when it is at a distance from the boundary of the חצר העליון, in such a manner <b>that it is possible to see from</b> the rise in the חצר התחתון into the חצר העליון, even after the wall, of ד' אמות high from the קרקע חצר התחתון, has been built. Therefore since the בעל חצר התחתון can see into the חצר העליון he must contribute to the entire wall, until it is ד' אמות high from קרקע חצר עליון (and the rise in חצר התחתון).<br>תוספות offers an alternate solution:<br><b>ורבינו יצחק מפרש דהתחתון מזיק לעליון כי קאי עליון<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The הגהות הב"ח amends this to read עליון בשפת חצירו כדאמרינן.</i>–</b><br><b>And the ר"י</b> <b>explains</b> that it is not necessary to assume that we are discussing a sloping חצר; but rather a regular חצר, that in its entirety is lower than the upper חצר. The reason the תחתון must assist the עליון up to ד' אמות from the ground of the עליון, is <b>for the תחתון</b> <b>damages the עליון when the</b> עליון <b>is standing</b> [<b>at the edge of his</b> own <b>חצר];</b> next to the dividing wall, which is ד' אמות higher than the ground of the תחתון. It is however less than ד' אמות higher than the ground of the עליון. Therefore when the עליון stands next to the (original [shortened] wall) he can be seen by the תחתון, if the תחתון is not immediately next to the wall, but at some distance from it.<br>תוספות proves his contention that even though the wall is ד' אמות high from the ground of the תחתון, the עליון can be seen when he stands. <sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See ‘Thinking it over’ # 3.</i><br><b>כדאמרינן לעיל<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Concerning two roofs on opposite sides of a ר"רה.</i> כי קאימנא חזו לי<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumable that a roof is more than ד' אמות higher than the רה"ר; nevertheless, the people of the ר"רה can see the בעל הגג when he stands.</i> –</b><br><b>As</b> the גמרא <b>previously stated, ‘when I stand up</b> the people of the ר"רה can <b>see me’.</b><br>תוספות concludes<br><b>ולכך צריך לסייע עד ד' אמות בחצר העליון:</b><br><b>And therefore;</b> since the תחתון can see the עליון standing <b>he is required to assist up to four</b> אמות above the ground level <b>of the upper חצר;</b> to prevent the בעל התחתון from seeing the בעל העליון even when he stands.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>There are two ways to understand why the תחתון must build up to ד' אמות above the ground level of the חצר העליון. A. The חצר of the תחתון slopes upwards as it recedes from the dividing wall enabling the תחתון to see over the lower wall. B. The תחתון can (usually) see the עליון above the lower wall when the עליון stands up [close to the wall].<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>1. תוספות assumes that the גמרא maintains that the תחתון must assist in building the wall ד' אמות above the ground level of the עליון.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See footnote # 1.</i> How does תוספות deduce this?<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See מטה יוסף אות קנו.</i><br>2. According to the פירוש ר"י, would there be any difference depending on how wide the חצר התחתון is (from the wall to the opposite boundary)?<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See נח"מ.</i><br>3. Why was it necessary for תוספות to prove that it is possible to see someone over a ד' אמות high wall, from the previous גמרא?<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See footnote # 5.</i> It seems quite factual.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See (עד"ז in) סוכ"ד אות מב ד"ה אבל דעת.</i><br>4. What are the relative advantages and disadvantages of both פירושים in תוספות? What are the practical differences להלכה?

Daf 7a



Line 1

<b>שוף אכריסך—שוף<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">There is a dispute between רש"י and תוספות as to the translation of 'שוף'.</i>… your stomach</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא discusses the case of a two story house that is sinking until the ceiling of the lower level is very low. The owner of the upper level can resist the efforts of the lower level owner to rebuild, by saying to him even though your ceiling is very low, nevertheless שוף אכריסך. There is a dispute between רש"י and תוספות as to the meaning of this phrase.<br>--------------------<br><b>פירש הקונטרס שחה קומתך –</b><br><b>רש"י</b> <b>interprets</b> this to mean, <b>bend down</b> to your stomach<b>.</b><br><b>ולרבינו יצחק נראה שוף לשון שפשוף שמתחכך בארץ:</b><br><b>However, it seems to the ר"י,</b> that the word שוף <b>means rubbing; that he is rubbing</b> his stomach <b>on the ground,</b> because he needs to ‘crawl on his stomach’<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The ר"י perhaps prefers his interpretation, for the prefix 'א' (in אכריסך) is usually translated as ‘on’. However according to רש"י, the translation here is ‘bend down to your stomach’. רש"י perhaps disagrees with the ר"י, because of the first question in ‘Thinking it over’</i> to get into the house<b>.</b><br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>There is a dispute between רש"י and תוספות if the word שוף means bending down (י"רש), or rubbing (תוספות).<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>1. It seems according to תוספות that the lower level is so low that he must crawl. However the גמרא states that if the ceiling fell below ten טפחים, he can force him to rebuild. If he has to crawl it would seem that it is lower than ten טפחים!<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See נח"מ.</i><br>2. Is there any practical difference between רש"י and תוספות (since the גמרא states the ten טפחים rule)?

<b>בוקי סריקי—Pitchers<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The word בוקי is the plural of בוקא which means a pitcher, as in the word בקבוק.</i> that are סריקי</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>רבה heard a statement in the name of רב נחמן, which he felt was absurd. He admonished the students, saying; ‘haven’t I told you that you should not hang בוקי סריקי on רב נחמן. תוספות wants to clarify the meaning of סריקי.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">It may be that סריקי usually refers to combing (of flax); as in מסרק. Our תוספות negates this translation as it is inappropriate to this discussion.</i><br>------------------------<br><b>אנשים רקים מתרגמינן גוברין סריקין (שופטים יא<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">'ג פסוק. The same words and same תרגום is found previously in שופטים ט,ד.</i>):</b><br><b>The</b> תרגום <b>translates</b> the words <b>אנשים ריקים</b><b>– ‘empty</b> headed <b>people,</b> as <b>people who are סריקין</b> <b>(empty</b> [coarse]<b>).</b> We see that the root of the word סריקי in Aramaic is ריק or empty in Hebrew; in the sense that it is lacking any (serious) content (and perhaps worse).<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>The translation of בוקי סריקי is ‘empty pitchers’.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See רש"י ע"ז לז,ב ד"ה בוקי, where he translates it to mean ריקים כדים; in the sense that it is lacking meaning.</i><br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>Was רבה merely ridiculing the ideas purported to be said in the name of רב נחמן, or was he also gently chastising those who attributed this statement to רב נחמן (according to תוספות)?

Line 7

<b>היינו הך—This is the same as that</b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא related two similar incidents where one petitioned his neighbor to rebuild (part of) the neighbor’s house.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In the first instance the ceiling of the lower level sunk and it was difficult for him to stand in his lower level house. The petitioner offered to rebuild the house. In the second case, the petitioner blocked the windows of his neighbor, and offered to rebuild that wall and install new windows which would not be blocked, by his wall. </i> In both incidents the neighbor’s position was upheld. He need not leave his house in order to have it rebuilt, regardless of the accommodations the petitioner will provide for him. The גמרא subsequently asked why there is a need to relate both incidents; they seem to teach us the exact same law. תוספות will question this assumption, and subsequently uphold it.<br>תוספות asks:<br><b>ואם תאמר והא אשמעינן בהאי עובדא דחדתא אעתיקא לא קאי דלא שמעינן מההיא דלעיל –</b><br><b>And if you will say; that in this</b> (latter) <b>story we are taught</b> something different, than in the first incident, namely <b>that a new</b> wall <b>will not stand atop<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">From תוספות answer it is evident that the phrase חדא אעתיקא means a combination of old and new, not only old atop of new. See footnote # 4.</i> of an old</b> wall; this is something <b>which we cannot derive from the previous</b> incident.<br>תוספות anticipates that one may argue that the question היינו הך may (also) mean that the second incident is sufficient; why relate the first story.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See ‘Thinking it over’.</i> תוספות responds:<br><b>ולעיל איצטריך כדאמרינן והני מילי דלא מטו כשורי למטה מי' וכולי –</b><br><b>And it was necessary</b> to relate <b>that previous</b> incident as well <b>as</b> the גמרא <b>mentions</b> there, <b>‘and these words</b> apply only <b>when the beams did not reach</b> down <b>below ten</b> טפחים, <b>etc.’</b> This ruling cannot be derived from the second incident. תוספות question is that it is necessary to relate both incidents for each one teaches us something that the other does not. Why does the גמרא maintain היינו הך that both incidents are the same?!<br>תוספות answers:<br><b>ויש לומר דמילתא דפשיטא היא דחדא חדתא וכולה עתיקא<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See footnote # 2.</i> לא קאי –</b><br><b>And one can say; that it is an obvious fact that one new</b> wall amongst <b>all old</b> walls <b>will not last.</b><br><b>ומשום הא לא הוה צריך לאתויי האי עובדא:</b><br><b>And</b> only <b>on account</b> to teach us <b>this</b> fact that לא קאי עתיקא וכולה חדתא חדא <b>it was not necessary to relate this incident.</b> We know this on our own. This is not a ruling of הלכה. This is a practical reality.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>It is not necessary for the גמרא to inform us of (physical) facts, which people are (generally) aware of.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>תוספות explains (in his question) why the first incident is (also) necessary.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See footnote # 3.</i> Seemingly this answer is necessary even according to the מסקנא of the גמרא;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The גמרא answers that the second incident teaches us this ruling is valid even when it is a storehouse. The question remains what does the first story teach us?</i> why does תוספות insert it here in his question?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">See מהר"ם ,מהרש"א. </i>

Line 8

<b>אספלידא—A house<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">תוספות will discuss the precise translation of an אספלידא.</i></b><br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא relates that two brothers divided their father’s estate. One received an אספלידא, the other a תרביצא (garden). Subsequently the בעל התרביצא built a wall (on his property) which blocked the light to the אספלידא. רב חמא ruled that the בעל התרביצא had the right to build in his property, even though the בעל האספלידא may claim that originally I received an אספלידא and you made it into a dark room. תוספות will discuss what is the translation of אספלידא.<br>--------------------------<br><b>פירש רש"י טרקלין יפה –</b><br><b>רש"י interprets</b> אספלידא to mean <b>a beautiful banquet hall<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See רש"י ד"ה אספלידא and following תוספות ד"ה א"ל.</i> –<br>ובערוך פירש מערה כדמתרגם (תהלים נג<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">This should be amended to נז,א.</i>) מפני שאול במערה באספלידא –</b><br><b>And in the</b> ערוך <b>he interprets</b> אספלידא as <b>a cave as the תרגום</b> renders the word(s) in תהלים, ‘<b>from שאול in the מערה;’ the</b> תרגום<b></b> of במערה <b>is באספלידא.</b><br>תוספות disagrees with the ערוך:<br><b>ואומר רבינו יצחק דאספלידא דהכא אי אפשר להיות מערה –</b><br><b>And the ר"י</b> <b>says that the אספלידא</b> that is mentioned <b>here</b> in our גמרא, <b>it is impossible that it refers to a cave –<br>מדקאמר )נמי( [נהי<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See gloss in margin (רש"ש).</i>]דעלו להדדי בכשורי והודרי ובמערה ליכא כשורי והודרי –</b><br><b>Since</b> the גמרא <b>states,</b> concerning the dividing of the אספלידא (and the תרביצא)<b>; ‘granted that they appraised each other</b>’s share <b>concerning the slats and the beams’</b> of the אספלידא, etc. It is evident from the גמרא that the אספלידא has הורדי וכשורי. <b>However in a cave there are no וכשורי הורדי,</b> proving that אספלידא is not a cave.<br>תוספות offers an additional proof that אספלידא in our גמרא cannot be a cave:<br><b>ועוד מדקאמר מעיקרא אספלידא והשתא אידרונא<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The מסרות הש"ס amends this to אינדרונא</i> ובמערה ליכא אורה כלל<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See ‘Thinking it over’.</i> –</b><br><b>And furthermore, since</b> the גמרא <b>states</b> that the owner of the אספלידא claims that originally I had an אספלידא and now (after you blocked me) it is a dark room; inferring that originally it was (very) well lit <b>– however in a cave there is no light at all.</b> Therefore אספלידא cannot mean a cave (in our גמרא).<br>תוספות offers a new interpretation of אספלידא:<br><b>ומפרש רבינו יצחק דאספלידא דהכא הוי אכסדרה שיש בה אורה גדולה שפרוצה ברוח אחד –</b><br><b>And the ר"י</b> <b>explained that the</b> אספלידא <b>here</b> in our גמרא <b>is an</b> (open) <b>portico that is very well lit for one side is</b> completely <b>open</b> without a wall –<br><b>כדאמרינן בלא יחפור (לקמן דף כה,א) עולם דומה לאכסדרה וכולי –</b><br><b>As</b> the גמרא <b>states in</b> פרק <b>לא יחפור, ‘the world is similar to an אכסדרה, etc.’,</b> that on the northern border it is not surrounded, indicating that an אכסדרה has no wall on one side.<br>תוספות offers proof that an אספלידא is an אכסדרה:<br><b>וכן מוכח בהקומץ רבה (מנחות דף לג,ב ושם דיבור המתחיל אספלידא) דאמר אביי –</b><br><b>And this is also evident from</b> the גמרא in פרק <b> הקומץ רבה</b>  that an אספלידא and an אכסדרה are the same. The גמרא there relates <b>that אביי</b> <b>said –<br>חזינא להו לאספלידי דבי מר דאית להו פצימי ולית להו מזוזה –</b><br><b>I have seen the</b> various <b>איספלידי</b> <b>of the master</b> (רבה) <b>that they have</b> door <b>posts and they do not have מזוזות</b> affixed to them.<br><b>ופריך מיתיבי בית שער ואכסדרה ומרפסת חייבין במזוזה:</b><br><b>And</b> the גמרא there <b>challenges</b> s'אביי assertion that they did not have מזוזות, <b>we will refute</b> you, for we learnt in a ברייתא that <b>a gatehouse and a portico and a porch require a מזוזה.</b> The question is how can it be that the מר דבי אספלידי do not have a מזוזה, since the ברייתא states that אכסדרה, בית שער and a מרפסת do require a מזוזה. An אספלידא is (certainly), neither a בית שער or a מרפסת. Obviously the challenge to אביי was from אכסדרה.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">In addition, the גמרא resolves the challenge to אביי that the ברייתא is discussing a different type of אכסדרה.</i> That proves that an אכסדרה and an אספלידא are one and the same.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>תוספות mentions three interpretations of אספלידא. A. רש"י - a beautiful banquet hall. B. ערוך – a cave. C. תוספות – a portico with one wall completely open; an אכסדרה.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>Why did not תוספות refute the ערוך from the original protest of the בעל האספלידא, namely that you are making it dark for me (קא מאפלת עלי)?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See footnote # 6</i> Why is that not sufficient proof that an אספלידא cannot mean a cave?<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See מהר"ם.</i>
<b>אמר ליה בדידי קבנינא—He told him: I am building in my</b> property<br><br>O<small>VERVIEW</small><br>The גמרא relates the story of the brothers who divided the estate; one taking the garden, the other the house. Subsequently the garden owner built a wall, on his own property, blocking the light of the house. The homeowner complained, arguing that you are darkening my home; you are turning it into a dark room, etc. רב חמא ruled in favor of the garden owner. The issue at hand is to what degree is the garden owner permitted to block out the light of the homeowner. תוספות will discuss three opinions on this matter.<br>-------------------------------<br><b>פירש הקונטרס אתה אין לך עלי חזקת אורה של שלש שנים<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">It is the opinion of  רש"י בד"ה בדפנשאי(according to תוספות), that the window owner does not acquire any right of lighting for his window unless he had the window lighting for three years and his neighbor did not object. Otherwise the neighbor is permitted to build a wall on his own property immediately opposite the window depriving it from any light at all.</i> –</b><br><b>רש"י</b> <b>explained</b> that the builder of the wall (בעל התרביצא) said to the owner of the building (בעל האספלידא) <b>you have not acquired from me</b> as of yet <b>the rights of</b> proper <b>lighting</b> which require <b>three years</b> to establish<b>.</b> Therefore I am entitled to build on my property any building, even if it will deprive you from adequate lighting.<br>תוספות asks on רש"י:<br><b>ותימה שהיה יכול להאפילו עליו שלא יהא לו בטרקלין<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See רש"י ד"ה אספלידא who translates אספלידא to mean יפה טרקלין.</i> אורה כלל<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">תוספות assumes that he blocked the light of the טרקלין completely since רש"י states that the בעל התרביצא claims that the בעל האספלידא has no rights to any light (since there was no חזקת ג' שנים). This is supported by the fact that the בעל האספלידא stated: a) קא מאפלת עלי and b) אינדרונא לי משוית השתא, indicating there was no light at all. תוספות does not elaborate why it is a תימה; it seems self-evident that this cannot be permitted. See מהרש"א and בל"י אות קנד.</i> –</b><br><b>And it is incredible that</b> the garden owner <b>was permitted to darken his</b> house to the extent <b>that he should have no light at all in his ‘banquet hall’.</b><br>תוספות has an additional question on רש"י:<br><b>ועוד דמאי קאמר באוירא לא עלו אהדדי<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The גמרא explains that the בעל האספלידא has no air/light rights, since when they assessed the value of the אספלידא, they only took into account the actual value of the building materials, not air/light value.</i> –</b><br><b>And furthermore, what is it that</b> the גמרא <b>states they did not</b> include the open <b>air</b> rights <b>when they assessed each other’s</b> property values. How can the גמרא maintain that!<br><b>פשיטא דעלו נמי באוירא דבית בלא אורה אינו שוה כלום –</b><br><b>It is obvious that they also included</b> in their <b>assessment</b> the value of the open <b>air</b> rights, <b>for a house without light is worthless.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The two brothers divided their father’s estate; one took the garden, the other the house. The house was worth more than the garden, therefore they evaluated the respective values of the house and the garden, after which the owner of the house paid the owner of the garden half the difference to equalize their portions. It is obvious that when they assessed the value of the house it was assessed as a normal house with sufficient lighting. Otherwise, if there was no lighting, the value of the house would be (next to) nothing. How then can the גמרא state that they did not evaluate the lighting!</i></b><br>תוספות offers a different interpretation of the גמרא:<br><b>ומפרש רבינו תם שמאספלידא היה יכול לראות לשדותיו דרך התרביצא –</b><br><b>And the</b> ר"ת <b>explains that from</b> within <b>the אספלידא</b> the owner of the אספלידא <b>was able to see his</b> own <b>fields</b> that were distant from the אספלידא <b>by way of the תרביצא;</b> until the בעל התרביצא built the wall which prevented the בעל האספלידא from observing his fields.<br>תוספות responds to an anticipated difficulty with this interpretation:<br><b>ודקאמר מאפלת עילווי היינו שהיה מעכבו שלא היה יכול לראות שדותיו –</b><br><b>And that which</b> the גמרא <b>quotes</b> the בעל האספלידא complaining, <b>‘you are darkening upon me,’</b> which would seemingly indicate that the new wall did not merely prevent him from observing his fields but rather, as רש"י maintains, darkened his house; תוספות responds that the expression מאפלת עילווי: <b>means that</b> the בעל התרביצא <b>was preventing</b> the בעל האספלידא <b>so that he was not able to see his fields.</b> The word ‘darkening’ need not be understood literally, but figuratively; I cannot see my fields because of your wall. My fields are in darkness they cannot be seen.<br>This approach will also resolve an additional difficulty:<br><b>וקרי לה נמי אידרונא<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See מסרות הש"ס that the word אידרונא should read אינדרונא (throughout [תוספות]).</i> שלא היה יכול להביט למרחוק –</b><br><b>And</b> the בעל האספלידא <b>also referred to</b> the אספלידא after the wall was built as an <b>אידרונא</b> <b>– a darkened room;</b> again it is not to be understood literally but rather the בעל האספלידא meant to say <b>that he could not look afar;</b> his view was blocked.<br><b>וכן מפרש ההוא דלקמן<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">ז,ב.</i> אין להם חלונות זה על זה –</b><br><b>And</b> the ר"ת <b>similarly interprets that</b> which the גמרא states <b>later</b> concerning brothers who divided inherited property that <b>they have no window</b> rights <b>against each other</b>; any brother can build against his brother’s window.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">ר"ת understands this to mean that any brother who inherited a window in his property cannot expect to have the same view as it was when the father owned the property. Another brother may build in such a manner to restrict the previous view. However it certainly does not mean that another brother may board up his windows entirely, depriving him of any light at all. This is not permitted. The brothers retain a right for (a minimal amount of) light; but not of a grand view.</i><br>תוספות has a difficulty with the s'ר"ת interpretation:<br><b>ומיהו קשיא לרבינו יצחק דמאי קפריך מאי שנא מהא דתניא כולי<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">This is the ברייתא where two brothers divided the estate; one received the vineyard the other the wheat field. The vineyard owner retains ד' אמות adjacent to his vineyard in the wheat field. We derive from there that the original rights remain.</i> –</b><br><b>However the ר"י</b> <b>has a difficulty</b> with the s'ר"ת interpretation; <b>what does the</b> גמרא mean <b>by asking ‘how</b> does the case of אספלידא <b>differ from that which we learned in a</b> ברייתא<b>, etc’.</b><br><b>התם ודאי יש לו ד' אמות לפי שהם צורך לעבודת הכרם<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See the רש"י ,גמרא כו,א  here ד"ה ד' אמות and תוספות ב,א ד"ה אומר.</i> –</b><br><b>There</b> in the ברייתא the בעל הכרם <b>definitely acquires ד' אמות</b> in the שדה הלבן <b>for those</b> ד' אמות <b>are necessary to tend the</b> <b>vineyard –<br>אבל הכא זה לא היה צורך האספלידא משום הכי בדין קאמר ליה –</b><br><b>However here,</b> concerning the view to his fields; <b>this</b> viewing <b>is not a requirement of the אספלידא</b>. An אספלידא is made to live in; not necessarily to have a grand view, <b>therefore</b> the בעל התרביצא <b>justifiably said to</b> the בעל האספלידא ‘I am building in my own property’. The בעל התרביצא was not diminishing the intended use of the אספלידא. What is the s'גמרא question?!<br>תוספות offers another interpretation:<br><b>ונראה לרבינו יצחק דודאי היה מאפיל עליו האורה –</b><br><b>And the ר"י</b> <b>is of the opinion that certainly</b> this new wall <b>darkened</b> the אספלידא and diminished its <b>light –</b><br><b>שלא היה בו אורה גדולה כאשר צריך לאכסדרה<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See previous תוספות ד"ה אספלדיא, where the (same) ר"י translates אספלידא to mean an אכסדרה.</i> אבל עדיין היה בו אור גדול –</b><br><b>For it did not have a large</b> amount of <b>light which is appropriate for an אכסדרה however there was still plenty of light.</b> Therefore the בעל התרביצא was able to build, since there was still sufficient light in the אספלידא (even though it was less that it is customary).<br>תוספות anticipates a difficulty with this interpretation:<br><b>והא דאמר<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">ב,ב.</i> ומכנגדן מרחיק ד' אמות שלא יאפיל –</b><br><b>And that</b> which the ברייתא <b>says</b> that one must distance a wall <b>from opposite</b> the windows a distance of <b>ד' אמות</b> in order <b>that he should not darken</b> the windows.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Seemingly even if he builds the wall within ד' אמות of the windows there is also light, and nevertheless since it is not the usual light that he is accustomed to, one may not block out that light. Therefore here too, since the אספלידא generally receives a great deal of light, he should be prohibited from diminishing the usual and customary amount of light.</i><br>תוספות responds; there, concerning the prohibition from building a wall within ד' אמות of the windows; the term שלא יאפיל does not mean that he is merely darkening his room that it will not have as much light as before, but rather שלא יאפיל means:<br><b>היינו שלא יאפיל לגמרי עד שלא יהא ראוי להשתמש בו יפה –</b><br><b>That he should not darken him completely to</b> the extent <b>that he cannot use the</b> room <b>properly.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">When a wall is built within ד' אמות of a window it is not merely that the light is diminished, but rather we consider the room entirely dark, that it cannot be used, in a normal manner. That is why it is prohibited from building within ד' אמות. However here by the אספלידא even after the wall was built, there would still be sufficient lighting in the אספלידא for normal use.</i></b><br>תוספות goes on to explain the גמרא according to the ר"י:<br><b>ומשום הכי קרי ליה אידרונא משום דלגבי אכסדרה אידרונא היא –</b><br><b>And</b> the reason <b>wherefore he called it an אידרונא is because compared to</b> the light required for <b>an אכסדרה</b> this is now considered <b>an אידרונא,</b> since it had much less light than an אכסדרה usually has.<br><b>והשתא נמי אתי שפיר דלא עלו להדדי באוירא שהוא צורך האכסדרא:</b><br><b>And now it is also properly</b> understood that the גמרא says <b>that they did not</b> take the <b>air</b>space into consideration when they <b>assessed</b> the respective values of the תרביצא and the אספלידא; that airspace is referring to the airspace <b>that is required for an אכסדרה;</b> it was only that additional airspace that was not assessed. However the normal air space that is required that there should be sufficient lighting was certainly taken into consideration.<br><br>S<small>UMMARY</small><br>רש"י is of the opinion that if one does not have a חזקת ג' שנים for his air/light rights, a neighbor may block out his entire light, if he builds on his property. The ר"ת and the ר"י disagree with רש"י, and maintain that one’s right to light must be respected, even without חזקת ג' שנים. The ר"ת interprets the story of the אספלידא that merely his view was blocked. The ר"י interprets it, that the extensive light of the אכסדרה was diminished to a normal house light.<br><br>T<small>HINKING IT OVER</small><br>Explain the differences between רש"י and the ר"י ור"ת concerning whether and why blocking entirely the light is permitted or prohibited.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See סוכ"ד אות ז.</i><br>Is there a difference להלכה between the ר"ת and the ר"י?<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See רא"ש אות כ.</i>
